posts.cooked:
Hello,

Our team is wondering how to measure torque in code. Specifically, we want to measure torque spikes on TalonFX motors as a safety measure to prevent our motors from running in the opposite direction and hitting into our robot.  We‚Äôre coding in Java. Our initial idea is to measure voltage and check if the voltage suddenly jumps up. However, we‚Äôre currently using the .getMotorOutputVoltage() function, but we don‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs the right function to use to measure voltage because I also noticed the .getBusVoltage() . Also, we don‚Äôt know the threshold to detect a torque spike. Would anyone know how to find this value?

Thank you. This will make our robot much safer.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
I think current is what you are looking for rather than voltage.

As motor load increases, current draw increases.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
If what you are trying to ‚Äúdetect‚Äù is a motor driving a mechanism into a hard stop - like the robot chassis - you probably want to look at limit switches.

You can infer certain conditions from current consumption but in the case of mechanism stops, limit switches are the real winner.

If you‚Äôre trying to do something else, you‚Äôll need to go into some detail‚Ä¶

posts.cooked:
As of right now, we can‚Äôt place a limit switch where we need to. There‚Äôs reasons why, but long story short, we can‚Äôt place a limit switch where it would need to go.

To your first response, is there a certain threshold that the current should cross that would indicate a torque spike.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: That‚Äôs up to you to figure out for your mechanism.  You‚Äôll likely want to consult the motor spec sheets and do a little math.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked: ^^ To first order of magnitude, the torque on a motor is linearly proportional to the current draw (or current generation).  Reading the current draw of the PDP/PDH channel your motor‚Äôs controller is connected to is the quick and dirty solution.  Whether it‚Äôs good enough for your purposes is more easily evaluated by trying it than by doing the math, especially if you‚Äôre not sure of the math and don‚Äôt have a lot of time.  If you want to express this and sound like you know what you‚Äôre doing, say that you determined this threshold empirically.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
somerandomuser:

As of right now, we can‚Äôt place a limit switch where we need to. There‚Äôs reasons why, but long story short, we can‚Äôt place a limit switch where it would need to go.

Keep in mind in regards to limit switches, they don‚Äôt have to go only in the location where the mechanism makes contact.  You can work out a mount or some sort of actuating tab or something for a limit switch at some other place along an arm that might be much more practical for your design.

As you move closer to your pivot point, you‚Äôll have less movement so the location of the limit switch might get a little more precise.

Another alternative might be to do a more direct software limit that‚Äôs not current-related - you could add an encoder to the pivot (maybe) and measure the angle of movement and set a limit that way.

In regards to actually doing this with a current limit (which could be done), this is a lot empirical but some aspects could be calculated (as others have mentioned).  Build it. measure it, set a margin.

The type of motor, the mechanics of the arm, the gear box, the weight of what you‚Äôre manipulating; it all comes into play.  You can measure the ‚Äúnormal‚Äù draw to get an idea of what you need to make it work - say you see 10A.  Maybe figure in a little bit of a margin in the event that this might just not be enough - maybe you call 15A ‚Äúnormal‚Äù.  You can see how much current you draw when the mechanism stalls - maybe it‚Äôs 25A.  That might be your ceiling.

Keep in mind that this sort of mechanism and control strategy can really lean into your mechanical aspects of you design, strength of the arm, the pivot, whatever it leans against on the robot to go into stall.  If any of those things are too close to their mechanical limits or too dainty strength-wise, you might get into trouble; especially after multiple cycles.

It could be made to work but it‚Äôs probably not the primary go-to if you‚Äôve got any other options‚Ä¶
